column1: Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection that involves the lungs, but may spread to other organs.
Ask your doctor whether others with whom you work or live should be tested for TB.
The only way to get rid of the germs is to take your TB medicines the way your doctor has instructed.
If your doctor is worried that you may not be taking all the medicines as directed, they may arrange to have someone meet with you every day or a few times a week to watch you take your TB drugs.
Most people do not have very bad side effects from TB medicines.

Problems to watch out for and tell your doctor about include: - Achy joints - Bruising or easy bleeding - Fever - Less or no appetite - Tingling or aches in your toes, fingers, or around your mouth - Upset stomach, nausea or vomiting, and stomach cramps or pain - Yellow skin or eyes Call your doctor if you have: - Any of the side effects listed above - New symptoms of active TB, such as cough, fever or night sweats, shortness of breath, or pain in the chest
